node.contents: I'm feeding in an array of length 8 say if trials is 100 it might be of the form 93 5 2 0 0 0 0 0, but whatever the values I have in the array I only get 0.6 back. If anyone can see if I'm making a stupid error that would be great. I've tried it with a for loop but keep getting 0.6.

astNode.text: I'm feeding in an array of length 8 say if trials is 100 it might be of the form 93 5 2 0 0 0 0 0, but whatever the values I have in the array I only get 0.6 back. If anyone can see if I'm making a stupid error that would be great. I've tried it with a for loop but keep getting 0.6.

elements.contents: static void getMetric(int[]a, int trials){ double metric = 0; int i =0; while(i<8){ if(i==0){ double x = (a[0] / trials) - (2 / 15); metric += Math.abs(x); i++; } else if(i>0 && i<7){ double x = (a[i] / trials) - 0.1; metric += Math.abs(x); i++; } else{ double x = (a[7] / trials) - (2 / 15); metric += Math.abs(x); System.out.println(""+metric); i++; } } }

units.rawText: static void getMetric(int[]a, int trials){ double metric = 0; int i =0; while(i<8){ if(i==0){ double x = (a[0] / trials) - (2/ 15); metric += Math.abs(x); i++; } else if(i>0&& i<7){ double x = (a[i] / trials) - 0.1; metric += Math.abs(x); i++; } else{ double x = (a[7] / trials) - (2/ 15); metric += Math.abs(x); System.out.println(""+metric); i++; } } }

node.contents: no, this doesn't work: (double)(2 / 15) == 0.0, because it first does the integer division and then convert to double

astNode.text: no, this doesn't work: (double)(2 / 15) == 0.0, because it first does the integer division and then convert to double

node.contents: So instead of a[0] / trials, you should have a[0] / (double) trials;

astNode.text: So instead of a[0] / trials, you should have a[0] / (double) trials;

node.contents: It looks like you need double-division and not int-division. Remember:

astNode.text: It looks like you need double-division and not int-division. Remember:

elements.contents: int a = 96; int b = 100; double c = a / b; //will be 0.0!

units.rawText: int a = 96; int b = 100; double c = a / b; //will be 0.0!

node.contents: so the following program should do the same, but more correct, I think (and shorter):

astNode.text: so the following program should do the same, but more correct, I think (and shorter):

elements.contents: static void getMetric(int[] a, int trials){ double metric = Math.abs((((double)a[0]) / trials) - (2 / 15)); for (int i = 1; i < 7; i++) { metric += Math.abs((((double)a[i]) / trials) - 0.1); } metric += Math.abs((((double)a[7]) / trials) - (2 / 15)); System.out.println(""+metric); }

units.rawText: static void getMetric(int[] a, int trials){ double metric = Math.abs((((double)a[0]) / trials) - (2/ 15)); for (int i = 1; i < 7; i++) { metric += Math.abs((((double)a[i]) / trials) - 0.1); } metric += Math.abs((((double)a[7]) / trials) - (2/ 15)); System.out.println(""+metric); }

node.contents: and that one is even more reable and robust:

astNode.text: and that one is even more reable and robust:

elements.contents: static void getMetric(int[] a, int trials){ double metric = calcMetricDiff(a[0], trials, 2.0 / 15.0); for (int i = 1; i < a.length - 1; i++) { metric += calcMetricDiff(a[i], trials, 0.1); } metric += calcMetricDiff(a[a.length-1], trials, 2.0 / 15.0); System.out.println(""+metric); } private static double calcMetricDiff(double val, int trials, double diff) { return Math.abs((val / trials) - diff); }

units.rawText: static void getMetric(int[] a, int trials){ double metric = calcMetricDiff(a[0], trials, 2.0/ 15.0); for (int i = 1; i < a.length - 1; i++) { metric += calcMetricDiff(a[i], trials, 0.1); } metric += calcMetricDiff(a[a.length-1], trials, 2.0/ 15.0); System.out.println(""+metric); } private static double calcMetricDiff(double val, int trials, double diff) { return Math.abs((val / trials) - diff); }
